ai-mil3.8:0.2_0: Sañjikāputta’s questions: Questioning in the eyes,
ai-mil3.8:2.1_0: (They said): “It is not so, great king, the wise one is not.”
ai-mil3.8:2.2_0: “Yes, my teacher is like; I will be like that.”
ai-mil3.8:2.3_0: The king answers to him: “After giving a simile of the horse-hair rope, the royal bull elephant on the forecourt of a hundred thousand coins, but whatever royal longs there is—where else the eighth day.”
ai-mil3.8:2.5_0: “Sir, I know what you’re doing. Because of this protection and that it is proper for me.”
ai-mil3.8:2.6_0: “How do you think, chief, when in order to rebuke Migāra’s mother lady, may I not believe anything!”
ai-mil3.8:2.7_0: How on earth can I guard my confidence?”
ai-mil3.8:2.9_0: “Sir, suppose a lion, a gambler with joined palms, that’s where the king of beasts have left.
ai-mil3.8:2.10_0: In the same way, even when I’m living at home I’d still inside a house.
ai-mil3.8:2.11_0: If I were to go forth, I wouldn’t have long been infatuated, I would have long to live.”
ai-mil3.8:3.1_0: Once again he got up from his seat and left.
ai-mil3.8:3.2_0: Not long after he had left, the venerable ones thought,
ai-mil3.8:3.3_0: “What was I asking about with my question? Why are I dispelled by him?”
ai-mil3.8:3.5_0: “I’ve asked everything, all-knowed by the Dragons.”
ai-mil3.8:3.6_0: as did he had the Sangha of nuns in the monastery.
ai-mil3.8:3.7_0: “What was my brought to me? Why did I ask for the king?”
ai-mil3.8:3.9_0: “I’ve asked all that is well spoken.”
ai-mil3.8:4.1_0: Then when the night had passed, having dressed in the morning time, went to Migāra’s house, and sat down on the seat spread out.
ai-mil3.8:4.2_0: On one occasion Migāra sat down to one side, and said to the king,
ai-mil3.8:5.3_0: ‘What was I asked, what was I practiced?’
ai-mil3.8:6.4_0: ‘What is it I asking you about, Mili?’
ai-mil3.8:7.1_0: The conclusion of the enquiry is finished.
